newsitem.title: KYRGYZSTAN: Kyrgyz, Uzbek, Kazakh heads mull security, economy.
newsitem.headline: Kyrgyz, Uzbek, Kazakh heads mull security, economy.

text.p: The leaders of the former Soviet Central Asian states of Kyrgyzstan, Kazakhstan and Uzbekistan meet on Thursday to discuss security in light of the fighting in Afghanistan and ways to increase cooperation.
"The presidents will exchange views on the situation in Afghanistan, which influences the situation in Central Asia," Kyrgyz Foreign Minister Muratbek Imanaliyev told reporters.

Kyrgyz President Askar Akayev, Uzbek President Islam Karimov and Kazakh President Nursultan Nazarbayev will spend two days in the lakeside mountain resort of Cholpon Ata, some 240 km (150 miles) east of the Kyrgyz capital, Bishkek.

The three states, covering a territory larger than Western Europe but populated by just 44 million people, have repeatedly voiced fears of the possible advent of militant, Taleban-type Islam from over the Afghan border in the wake of the war there.

Stronger cooperation among the recession-battered economies is also on the agenda of the meeting, including measures needed to bring to life the inert Central Asian Bank for Cooperation and Development, set up in 1994.
The three former Soviet republics, united by common roots in old Turkic tribes, founded the Central Asian Union in 1994, in a bid to boost their political, economic and cultural ties.
